{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3749767,"name":"Gabriel","username":"Gabs","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gabs/{size}/270631_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-27T17:14:56.385Z","cooked":"

Hi everyone,

I’m currently working on improving the robot’s pose estimation on my team (Steel Bulls #9465), and I’ve been running into some difficulties. Our goal is to get a reliable estimation of the robot’s position and orientation on the field, but I’m struggling with a few points:

  • How to properly fuse data from encoders, gyro, and vision (Limelight) in WPILib’s pose estimator.

  • Understanding when to trust vision measurements vs odometry, especially when there’s noise or no target.

  • Making sure the estimated pose doesn’t drift too much during autonomous.

I’ve read the WPILib docs and some examples, but I’m still not sure if I’m setting things up correctly or if I’m missing some important configuration details.

So my main question is: what would be the best way to handle robot pose estimation in FRC? Should I rely mostly on odometry and only use vision for corrections, or is there a recommended approach to balance both?

If anyone has advice, best practices, or examples of how you’ve handled pose estimation in your robots, I’d really appreciate it!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":2,"updated_at":"2025-09-27T17:14:56.385Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":89,"readers_count":88,"score":27.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":506639,"topic_slug":"difficulty-with-robot-pose-estimation-in-frc","display_username":"Gabriel","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":77330,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/difficulty-with-robot-pose-estimation-in-frc/506639/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3749776,"name":"Tim Winters","username":"ArchdukeTim","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/archduketim/{size}/256125_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-27T17:36:07.293Z","cooked":"
Gabs:

recommended approach to balance both

This is definitely recommended, since you’ll get the benefit of vision being a better source of truth, but odometry can do faster tracking, and continues providing data 100% of the time, whereas vision only works when a tag is visible.

How to properly fuse data from encoders, gyro, and vision (Limelight) in WPILib’s pose estimator.

If you’re using swerve drive, wpilib has a SwervePoseEstimator that is meant for swerve drive. You pass in the values of the swerve modules (distance and angle of each module), and it determines the pose. You can also call addVisionMeasurement to add in vision measurements. It will fuse them together for you.

Understanding when to trust vision measurements vs odometry, especially when there’s noise or no target.

Generally, you trust vision more when there are multiple targets in view, and trust it less the further you get from the tags. You can tell the pose estimator how much to trust a reading based of these criteria

Making sure the estimated pose doesn’t drift too much during autonomous.

It shouldn’t drift too much if your camera location in code matches its real world location. Odometry estimation can be improved by using 250 Hz. CTRE enables this with their swerve API if you have a canivore. Rev has it upcoming it looks like in 2026.
